item.title: How will it benefit my organization?
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
The main purpose of BCM is to ensure that the organization has a response to major disruptions that threaten its survival. Whilst this must be worthwhile in itself, there are other benefits that can be gained by embracing BCM as a management discipline. Some organizations have statutory and regulatory requirements either specifically for BCM or more generally for ‘risk management’ as part of their corporate governance requirement. An appropriate BCM plan will satisfy both the specific requirements and contribute both a response to specific risks and to the overall ‘risk awareness’ of an organization. However the primary driver for BCM should always be that it is undertaken because it adds value to an organization and the products and services it delivers rather than because of governance or regulatory considerations.

“For many companies, BCM will address some…key risks and help them achieve compliance". Nigel Turnbull, Chairman of Turnbull Committee on UK Corporate Governance. Businesses selling to other businesses have used BCM as a competitive advantage to gain new customers and to improve margins by using it as a demonstration of ‘customer care’. A thorough review of the business through Business Impact Assessment and Plan exercises can highlight business inefficiencies and focus on priorities that would not otherwise have come to light.

Conclusion There is a lot of ground to cover in performing comprehensive Business Continuity Management.  This web site strives to provide information in most of these areas. Pages on many of the planning areas are provided that will describe the issues and provide information and resource to assist you in your BCM efforts.

item.title: Security Strategy
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
2009-2011 Information Security Strategy for securitysense
How to develop a IT/Information security strategy for your company?  

An information security strategic plan should include, at a minimum, an assessment of the current state of the program, a defined target state that is achievable within the three-year strategic planning window, a gap analysis and a road map for closing the gaps.

  Key Findings

• A consistent framework can be defined that supports risk mitigation control objectives, architecture and

process objectives, but the framework varies in scale and by the maturity level of the organization it's

being applied to.

• Small or immature organizations should focus on very simple frameworks.

• Consistent, incremental improvements are much more likely to succeed than rapidly forced changes.

  Recommendations • Develop and document an information security strategic plan and use it to generate annual tactical plans that, when executed, move the overall maturity of the security program upward. • Develop a process to review and refine the strategic plan annually.   ANALYSIS

Many organizations and security officers are approaching the creation of a strategic plan for information security for the first time, or have expressed a desire to use previously unimplemented best practices in creating the next iteration of one. Although there is no industry standard for the contents of such a plan, Securitysense has recommended organizations by using a model that has proved to be an effective communication tool with the numerous interested parties (including senior management), as well as a reasonable tracking mechanism for multiyear progress reports. While the model can be applied by organizations of any size and in any industry, the details vary based on the scale of the organization and the starting maturity level of the various effected organizational units.

The information security strategic plan should not be viewed as a stand-alone document. It should exist as one part of a set of planning documents that start with a charter and a vision statement, but that also extends beyond the strategic plan into tactical and communications plans. Each of these has a role in providing context and action ability for the strategic plan. Organizations that have an established enterprise architecture (EA) function should leverage the existing EA disciplines, processes and standards to ensure that the strategic plan for information security is aligned with the EA strategy (see "Architecting Security: Different Approaches"). Securitysense generally considers three years to be an appropriate window for strategic planning for information security. The charter and vision statements deal with longer-term directions, while the tactical and communications plans specify single-year operational considerations and projects.

The basic layout of the strategic plan is: • Introduction and executive summary • Strategic plan framework description • Current state • Desired state • Gap analysis • Prioritization plan • Roles and responsibilities   Introduction and Executive Summary The introduction should be written first, setting the purpose and scope of the document. The executive summary should be written last, showing only the final points of the document. The combination of executive summary and introduction should not exceed three pages, and, for most organizations, should be no more than two pages.   Strategic Plan Framework Description

The framework is the method by which the current state, desired state and gap analysis will be documented. An appropriate framework is one that can show overview (summarized) and detail (planning) information. The summary information should be expressed graphically. Frameworks should encompass controls, architecture and process elements to be complete.

For organizations with an established EA practice, an enterprise information security architecture (EISA) framework (see "The Structure and Content of an Information Security Architecture Framework") that aligns with the EA framework can act as an effective overall strategic security planning framework. Frameworks for this purpose can be derived from industry standards, from Securitysense research or from a combination of the two.   Some sources for framework structure and contents are: • Controls • International Organization for Standardization (ISO)/International Electro technical Commission (IEC) 27002 • Control Objectives for Information and Related Technology (COBIT) • U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) SP800-53 • Architecture • ISO10181 • ISO13335 • Processes • ISO/IEC 27001 • Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL)

In addition, Securitysense research can provide significant examples and guidelines for constructing such a framework (see the Recommended Reading section below). Large, mature organizations will require more-complex, detailed frameworks that focus largely on processes. Smaller or less mature organizations will find that simple frameworks suffice, and that all details can be left to the tactical planning stage, but that balanced (perhaps, not equal) attention to the three areas of controls, architecture and processes is required. An example of a simple framework for a low maturity organization might be a three-by-four grid showing the state of controls, technical architecture and processes for data, infrastructure, applications and people/behavior. Each cell in the grid can be assessed or targeted (depending on whether it is the current state or desired state framework copy) on a typical numeric maturity scale of 0 through 5, or assigned a color code of red, yellow or green (see Figure 1).

        Fig 1    

Larger or more-mature organizations will tend to focus more on process assessments, because controls and architecture tend to be well-defined, and the processes by which they are kept up to date will be defined and will be the primary lever for further maturation. Securitysense's "Toolkit: Risk Program Maturity Assessment 1.0" provides a full process-oriented framework that includes graphical reporting of information security, privacy, regulatory compliance and business continuity

programs (see Figure 2).

  Figure 2. Strategic Plan Contents: Current State Controls Architecture Process Data Infrastructure Applications People N/A Source: Securitysense (September 2008)   Current State

Use the framework described in the previous section to document the current state of each element contained within the framework. A brief text section describes each entry and justifies the assessment. Organizations with mature risk assessment processes may reference the current risk register to provide an assessment of existing controls.

Desired State

Document the desired state for each element within the framework. Three years is not a long time to achieve any sort of cultural change, nor for a significant reduction in the overall level of risk. Using a maturity scale from zero through five, with steps of one-half for each of the framework elements, allows sufficient granularity to show, at a strategic level, what degree of progress is being attempted. Brief text descriptions contain the background for each target value. Securitysense recommends that a change in maturity level of no more than a "2" be attempted for any framework element in a three-year period, unless exceptional resources and executive support can be assured (see Figure 3 for an example based on Figure 1).

    Figure 3. Strategic Plan Contents: Target State Controls Architecture Process Data Infrastructure Applications People N/A  

The desired state may also identify controls and technology areas that require change, retirement or replacement, if those have already been identified.

  Gap Analysis This section describes those elements of the framework that demonstrate variation between current and desired states (see Figure 4).   Figure 4. Strategic Plan Contents: Gap Analysis Controls Architecture Process +2 +1 +1 +2 +2 +1 +1 Data Infrastructure Applications People N/A +1   Prioritization Plan

There may be a natural order to resolving many of the issues identified via the gap analysis. Part of the three-year strategic plan should be guidance to tactical planners on how to prioritize the closure of those gaps, such that any natural order is optimized. Controls determine what should be achieved, but controls become meaningful only if the governance structure is functional. The IT organization needs direction via technical architecture to be efficient, but architecture requires guidance from controls. Operational processes related to technologies that are already in place depend, to some degree, on controls (what processes and technologies are needed) and architecture (which process elements and technologies are automated). As a result, a normal prioritization plan might be to start with governance, move to controls, then architecture and finally process. But this is a "greenfield" approach, and it may not be appropriate for organizations with variable levels of maturity in the current information security program or IT organizations in general. For example, a lack of maturity in strategic processes, such as risk assessment and security communications, which are not technology-dependent may demand earlier prioritization.

Therefore, the method by which priorities will be assigned in the tactical plans requires some

strategic guidance. More-granular prioritization of work should be included in tactical (annual) planning documents, and should be based on criteria such as the relative risk impact, the cost, the mean time to value and the availability of resources.

  Roles and Responsibilities

This section describes who is responsible for delivering and who is responsible for approving each strategic and tactical deliverable that results from this strategic plan. There are four sets of organizational areas that need to be mapped to deliverables and action plans:

• The security office

• Lines of business (LOBs) or federation issues (responsibilities that reside with persons or departments

that are affiliated with, but not reporting to, the central information security function)

• The IT organization

• Other business areas (typically, the functions that go on in headquarters, such as legal, HR and finance)

The security office's responsibilities should be easily extracted from the security charter. The authority, rights and obligations of LOB management and the IT organization should have been negotiated via the governance structure prior to, or as part of, the creation of this strategic plan. These authorities, rights and obligations are typically governed via some kind of information security steering committee. Other business areas may be surprised by their inclusion or may have expressed a need for involvement on their own, typically as a response to regulatory compliance needs.

One approach to documenting these roles and responsibilities that has been widely accepted by organization is the use of a responsible, accountable, consulted and informed (RACI) matrix. Once all these steps have been outlined, the executive summary can be written.

item.title: IT Security Framework – what is it ?
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
What is IT Security Framework?

Security framework is a code of practice and principles that includes process, policy and procedures used here at the company that protect and govern information security. The framework is a method of establishing, implementing, reviewing, maintaining and improving the security programs throughout the enterprise.

An IT Security framework is the foundation for an effective, enterprise wide security program. Many organization has adopted the International Standards Organization' s (ISO) Information Security Framework documented as ISO 27001 and 27002.This framework outlines many actions and controls needed to ensure the organizations appropriately protects the information assets it owns and creates.

The implementation of IT Security Framework is a multi-year project. Completing the initial work for implementing the various controls required to address information security concerns across an organizations varies as work must be parceled and planned to make the most gains using allocated resources.

Purpose of Security framework:

The purpose of this procedure is to achieve and maintain confidentiality, integrity and availability of Information and Information Processing Facilities.

This procedure applies to, but is not limited to, safeguarding of the following assets:

  • Physical assets (e.g. Network & Telco equipment computer hardware, communication facilities, information processing facilities).

  • Information/data (e.g. documents, databases, IT/Telecom- GSM Systems, Software).

  • Organization/Management.

  • The ability to provide a product or service.

  • People (knowledge, experience, skills).

  • Intangibles (e.g., goodwill, image).

item.title: Policy, Process, Procedure, Guideline and Standard - What is the Difference?
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
The terms ‘Policies’, ‘Processes’, and ‘Procedures’ are too often interchanged.  ‘Policies’, ‘Processes’, and ‘Procedures’ should be considered distinct types of documentation. The researching and developing documentation requires understanding the distinctions between a Policy, a Procedure, or a Process. All address related subject matter, but at a different level and with different types of content. Each type has a unique purpose that drives the content contained in each type of document. Describing the distinctions using who, what, where, when, why and how often helps to understand and properly structure them. 

Policy

An information security policy consists of high level statements relating to the protection of information across the business and should be produced by senior management.

 

The policy outlines security roles and responsibilities, defines the scope of information to be protected, and provides a high level description of the controls that must be in place to protect information. In addition, it should make references to the standards and guidelines that support it. Businesses may have a single encompassing policy, or several specific policies that target different areas, such as an email policy or acceptable use policy. From a legal and compliance perspective, an information security policy is often viewed as a commitment from senior management to protect information. A documented policy is frequently a requirement to satisfy regulations or laws, such as those relating to privacy and finance. It should be viewed as a business mandate and must be driven from the top (i.e. senior management) downwards in order to be effective.

  • Policies are the business rules and guidelines of a company that ensure consistency and compliance with the company’s strategic direction.  The Policies lay out the business rules under which a company, division, or department will operate.

  • Policies are the guidelines under which Procedures are developed.  There is not a one-to-one relationship between a Policy and a Procedure.  Policies are not part of the Procedure, because they cannot be properly structured.  However, the Procedure must reflect the business rules contained in the Policies. 

  • Policies address what the Policy is and its classification, who is responsible for the execution and enforcement of the Policy, and why the Policy is required.  

Process

  • Processes are related activities that produce a specific service or product (example, Procurement to Payment).  The majority of Processes cross departments or functional areas.  Each Process designates the connect points and where it crosses department lines.  The documentation presents the total Process.  It is helpful to be able to reference or drill down to the applicable Policy or Procedure for a Process step.  A Process map is a useful tool to graphically display the Process. 

  • Processes indicate where there is a separation of responsibilities and control points.  They are also very helpful to identify Policy and Procedure requirements.  Processes address who is responsible to perform the Process (department, division), what major functions are performed, and when the function is triggered.  

Procedure

Procedures consist of step by step instructions to assist workers in implementing the various policies, standards and guidelines.

 

Whilst the policies, standards and guidelines consist of the controls that should be in place, a procedure gets down to specifics, explaining how to implement these controls in a step by step fashion. For example, a procedure could be written to explain how to install Windows securely, detailing each step that needs to be taken to harden/secure the operating system so that it satisfies the applicable policy, standards and guidelines.

  • Procedures define the specific instructions necessary to perform a task or part of a Process.  Procedures can take the form of a work instruction, a desk top Procedure, a quick reference guide, or a more detailed Procedure. 

  • Procedures usually are structured by subject (for example, system instructions, report instructions, or Process tasks).  A Procedure usually addresses only a single task.  This separation enables Procedure components to be compiled into special Procedure manuals for specific audiences, end users, and purposes.

  • Procedures detail who performs the Procedure, what steps are performed, when the steps are performed, and how the Procedure is performed. 

Guidelines

 

Guidelines consist of recommended,non-mandatory controls that help support standards or serve as a reference when no applicable standard is in place.  

 

Guidelines should be viewed as best practices that are not usually requirements, but are strongly recommended. They could consist of additional recommended controls that support a standard, or help fill in the gaps where no specific standard applies. For example, a standard may require passwords to be 8 characters or more and a supporting guideline may state that it is best practice to also ensure the password expires after 30 days. In another example, a standard may require specific technical controls for accessing the internet securely and a separate guideline may outline the best practices for using the internet and managing your online presence.

Standard

There are many definitions of a 'standard'. Very generally, a standard might simply be defined as 'a set of rules for ensuring quality'.

ISO/IEC Guide 2:1996, definition 3.2 defines a standard as:

'A document established by consensus and approved by a recognized body that provides for common and repeated use, rules, guidelines or characteristics for activities or their results, aimed at the achievement of the optimum degree of order in a given context'.

Standards consist of specific low levelmandatory controls that help enforce and support the information security policy.

 

Standards help to ensure security consistency across the business and usually contain security controls relating to the implementation of specific technology, hardware or software. For example, a password standard may set out rules for password complexity and a Windows standard may set out the rules for hardening Windows clients.

In essence, a standard is an agreed way of doing something. It could be about making a product, managing a process, delivering a service or supplying materials – standards can cover a huge range of activities undertaken by organizations and used by their customers.

Standards are the distilled wisdom of people with expertise in their subject matter and who know the needs of the organizations they represent – people such as manufacturers, sellers, buyers, customers, trade associations, users or regulators.

item.title: Relationship between a policy, standard, guideline, and procedure

item.content:encoded: After a recent conversation explaining the relationship between a standard and guideline, I thought I’d post this diagram which clearly shows the relationship, at that of policies and procedures. Source: CISA Certified Information Systems Auditor Study Guide

item.title: Practical security framework sample : POLICY AND PROCEDURES
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
Following policy/procedure/template will be used as part of this security framework to ensure to the integrity, confidentiality and availability of resources of Securitysense.

SL

Policy/Procedure

Purpose

Target Employee
 1 Acceptable Use Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to outline the acceptable use of computer equipment at Securitysense.

 All Employees.
 2 Access Control Policy Ver2.0

This document defines the access control policy required to securely deploy, manage and control user network, operating system, application and database access.

 Group of Employee.System/Application Owner.
3 Antivirus policy Ver2.0

To establish requirements which must be met by all computers connected to Securitysense’s networks to ensure effective virus detection and prevention.

 All Employees.
 4 Backup policy Ver2.0

This policy establishes a backup strategy to address different types of service disruptions; minimal backup frequencies; recovery point objectives; and establishes the roles of various Staff positions having responsibilities relating to backup and recovery of critical systems and services.

 Authorized Employees.
 5 Data Centre Access Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to provide guidelines how Securitysense individuals will conduct themselves within the Datacenter.

 Authorized Employees.
 6 Database Security Policy Ver2.0

This policy states the requirements for securely storing and retrieving database usernames and passwords (i.e., database credentials) for use by a program that will access a database as well as overall database administration security for any Database running on of Securitysense’s networks.

 Authorized Employees.Database Team.
 7 E-mail Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of the policy is to ensure that we use the email system in an efficient but at the same time careful way when we communicate.

 All Employees.
 8 Encryption Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to provide guidance that limits the use of encryption to those algorithms that have received substantial public review and have been proven to work effectively.

 All Employees.
 9 Information Protection Policy Ver2.0

The Information Protection Policy aims at establishing a common understanding and approach to information security so to ensure better compliance by all concerned parties.

 All Employees.
 10 IT Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this IT policy is to address all issues relevant to standardization of hardware equipment and application software, software installation, deployment, access and security of IT/Technology resources in Securitysense Axiata Limited.

 All Employees.
 11 Information Classification Policy Ver2.0

The Information Classification Policy is intended to help employees determine what information can be disclosed to non-employees, as well as the relative sensitivity of information that should not be disclosed outside of Securitysense Axiata Limited without proper authorization.

 All Employees.
 12 Internet DMZ Security Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to define standards to be met by all equipment owned and/or operated by RAx located outside RAx's corporate Internet firewalls.

 Authorized Employees.
 13 Internet Usage Policy Ver2.0

Internet Usage Policy provides employees with rules and guidelines about the appropriate use of company equipment, network and Internet access.

 All Employees.
 14 Intrusion Detection Policy Ver2.0

It provides guidelines about intrusion detection implementation of the organizational networks and hosts along with associated roles and responsibilities.

 Authorized Employees.
 15 Log monitoring Policy Ver2.0

This policy reflects the Securitysense’s commitment to identify and implement security controls to keep risks to information system resources at reasonable and appropriate levels.

 Authorized Employees.
 16 Media Disposal Policy Ver2.0

This policy defines the steps necessary to implement Securitysense’s information system & media disposal.

 All Employees.
 17 End User Password Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to establish a standard for creation of strong passwords, the protection of those passwords, and the frequency of change.

 All Employees.
 18 Patch Management Policy Ver2.0

This will guide Windows OS patch update for Windows 2003 Enterprise Server R2

 Windows Team.
 19 Personal Computer Security Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this policy is to establish standards for the base configuration of internal Desktop equipment (PC/Laptop/Printer) that is owned and/or operated by Securitysense.

 All Employees.
 20 Remote Access Policy Ver2.0

The purpose of this Policy is to define standards for connecting to Securitysense’s network from any remote host, untrusted host, and remote network, including untrusted hosts on Securitysense’s intranet.

 All Employees.
 21 Information Security Risks Treatment Policy Ver2.0

This policy acknowledges that once risks are identified they must be treated.

item.title: Risk management - What it is?
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
What is risk management?

Businesses face risk every day. In fact, without risk a business or organization would not grow and thrive. Risk Management is the process which aims to help organizations understand, evaluate and take action on all their risks with a view to increasing the probability of their success and reducing the likelihood of failure.

Risk management gives comfort to stakeholders (shareholders, customers, employees and so on) that the business is being effectively managed and helps the organization confirm its compliance with corporate governance requirements.

Risk Management is relevant to all organizations whether they are in the public or private sector, or whether they are large or small. It should form part of the culture of the organization, with an effective policy and programme led by top management with clear responsibilities laid down for every manager and employee to be involved in the management of risk. It supports accountability, performance measurement and reward thus promoting efficiency at all levels.

The key stages of the risk management process are set out in the Risk Management Standard . Within larger organizations there is likely to be a need for a dedicated Risk Manager whose role would include:
  • setting policy and strategy for risk management,
  • being the primary champion of risk management at strategic and operational levels
  • building a risk aware culture within the organization including appropriate education and training
  • establishing internal risk policy and structures for business units
  • developing risk response processes including contingency and business continuity programmers
  • preparing reports for the board and the stakeholders
  Risk management requires a detailed knowledge and understanding of the organization and the processes involved in the business. As well as internal specialists there is a huge number of different advisers and consultants providing support to an organization’s risk management programmer. Because of this, risk management is a truly multi-disciplinary profession.

item.title: Enterprise risk management (ERM)
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Enterprise risk management (ERM) is the process of planning, organizing, leading, and controlling the activities of an organization in order to minimize the effects of risk on an organization's capital and earnings. Enterprise risk management expands the process to include not just risks associated with accidental losses, but also financial, strategic, operational, and other risks. In recent years, external factors have fueled a heightened interest by organizations in ERM. Industry and government regulatory bodies, as well as investors, have begun to scrutinize companies' risk-management policies and procedures. In an increasing number of industries, boards of directors are required to review and report on the adequacy of risk-management processes in the organizations they administer. Since they thrive on the business of risk, financial institutions are good examples of companies that can benefit from effective ERM. Their success depends on striking a balance between enhancing profits and managing risk. Business risk management, holistic risk management, and strategic risk management are synonyms.

item.title: Benefits
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Managing risk is a shared responsibility. It is inevitable that we will face risks, but these risks should be effectively managed to increase risk-adjusted returns, improve strategic judgement, and avoid extraordinary losses. Effective implementation of ERM will help ensure that: �� Securitysense has well-developed capabilities to consistently identify, measure and manage risk exposures �� risk and risk management are always important considerations in corporate judgement �� the likelihood that Robi will experience losses outside of its risk tolerance will be minimised

item.title: What You Can Do to Protect Yourself
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: The Information Security Branch has developed many of the following resources to help explain information security best practices and how you can keep ahead of identity theft, viruses, and social engineering tactics so you are prepared when an issue arises. Check them out!

item.title: How to help your kids use social websites more safely
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: These days, many kids draw little distinction between real life and online life. They may use social websites designed for children such as Webkinz or Club Penguin, or social websites designed for adults such as Windows Live Spaces, YouTube, MySpace, Flickr, Twitter, Facebook, and others. Whatever they're doing, they should understand that many of these web pages can be viewed by anyone with access to the Internet.

item.title: Ensure your kids follow age limits on the site
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: The recommended age for signing up for social websites is usually 13 and over. If your children are under the recommended age for these sites, do not let them use the sites. It is important to remember that you cannot rely on the services themselves to keep your underage child from signing up..

item.title: Operating System Security
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Operating System is the important program that runs on the computer. It performs basic tasks like recognizing the input from the keyboard, controlling various files and directories in the hard disk and also various peripheral devices like printers, scanners etc...It will control the program in such a way that they do not interfere with one another.It is responsible for securing the system by not allowing the unauthorized users to access the system.

item.title: Use Strong Passwords
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Passwords control access to files, programs, computers, hard drives and networks. They also deny access to unauthorized users. Poorly chosen passwords make it easier to break into your computer systems and expose to malicious attacks. In general, set up passwords and keep them secret never share it with others.

item.title: One of the common risk through e-mails is SPAM
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Spam is usually unwanted e-mail advertising about a product sent to list of e-mails or group of e-mail addresses. Generally spamming companies send e-mails to thousands of email addresses every day without confirming whether e-mail addresses are real or not .When ever you open a spam mail it alerts the spammer at the other end and confirms that email address is real and is active. This will continue to spam and sometimes directory of such email addresses are sold to other companies.

item.title: Picking and Protecting Password
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Learning to pick strong passwords and protect them appropriately is an important part. Why? Because passwords are still a primary means of authenticating your identity --a way to prove that you are really you to computers and networks.

item.title: Safer Emailing and Instant messaging
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded: Email services bring many benefits. It's an easy and convenient way to communicate with colleagues and with customers. But email is not an inherently secure medium of communication. It poses large security risks if used improperly.
